result.markdown:
---
title: "Testes Estatísticos"
format: html
editor: visual
warning: false
mensage: false
---


## Teste Inferencial Dois Grupos Independentes

O teste inferencial de dois grupos independentes, também conhecido como teste t de Student para amostras independentes, é uma ferramenta estatística utilizada para comparar a média de duas amostras de dados independentes. Esse teste é útil para determinar se existe uma diferença estatisticamente significativa entre as médias das duas amostras.


::: {.cell hash='aula6_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-1_a3d672ee84b5e166e443397dd1cd03cd'}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(gsheet)
library(tidyverse)
library(ggthemes)
library(report)
library(tidyverse)
library(emmeans)
library(multcomp)
library(multcompView)
library(DHARMa)
library(performance)
library(dbplyr)
library(dplyr)



mg <- gsheet2tbl("https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1bq2N19DcZdtax2fQW9OHSGMR0X2__Z9T/edit#gid=983033137")
```
:::


## Visualiza os Dados


::: {.cell hash='aula6_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-2_b6d4ab87352a61cf622fe75ebe582f31'}

```{.r .cell-code}
mg |>
  ggplot(aes (trat, comp))+
  geom_boxplot()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](aula6_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-2-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::


## Teste T


::: {.cell hash='aula6_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-3_4a9d110750753ae562fbbb627c5b0816'}

```{.r .cell-code}
mg2 <- mg |>
  pivot_wider(names_from = trat,
              values_from = comp)

teste1 <- t.test(mg2$control, mg2$Mg2,
       var.equal = TRUE)

shapiro.test(mg2$control)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```

	Shapiro-Wilk normality test

data:  mg2$control
W = 0.93886, p-value = 0.5404
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
shapiro.test(mg2$Mg2)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```

	Shapiro-Wilk normality test

data:  mg2$Mg2
W = 0.97269, p-value = 0.9146
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
hist(mg2$control)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](aula6_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-3-1.png){width=672}
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
hist(mg2$Mg2)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](aula6_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-3-2.png){width=672}
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
qqnorm(mg2$control)
qqline(mg2$control)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](aula6_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-3-3.png){width=672}
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
qqnorm(mg2$Mg2)
qqline(mg2$Mg2)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](aula6_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-3-4.png){width=672}
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
var.test(mg2$control, mg2$Mg2)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```

	F test to compare two variances

data:  mg2$control and mg2$Mg2
F = 0.67654, num df = 9, denom df = 9, p-value = 0.5698
alternative hypothesis: true ratio of variances is not equal to 1
95 percent confidence interval:
 0.1680428 2.7237436
sample estimates:
ratio of variances 
         0.6765394 
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
report(teste1)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
Effect sizes were labelled following Cohen's (1988) recommendations.

The Two Sample t-test testing the difference between mg2$control and mg2$Mg2
(mean of x = 15.68, mean of y = 10.52) suggests that the effect is positive,
statistically significant, and large (difference = 5.16, 95% CI [3.83, 6.49],
t(18) = 8.15, p < .001; Cohen's d = 3.65, 95% CI [2.16, 5.10])
```
:::
:::


## Dois Grupos Dependentes


::: {.cell hash='aula6_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-4_e33c5ac6697b6327a28d347fa709d382'}

```{.r .cell-code}
escala <- gsheet2tbl("https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1bq2N19DcZdtax2fQW9OHSGMR0X2__Z9T/edit#gid=1729131173")

escala |>
  ggplot(aes(assessment, acuracia))+
  geom_boxplot()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](aula6_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-4-1.png){width=672}
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
escala2 <- escala |>
  dplyr::select(assessment, rater, acuracia) |>
  pivot_wider(names_from = assessment,
              values_from = acuracia)

shapiro.test(escala2$Unaided)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```

	Shapiro-Wilk normality test

data:  escala2$Unaided
W = 0.7748, p-value = 0.007155
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
shapiro.test(escala2$Aided1)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```

	Shapiro-Wilk normality test

data:  escala2$Aided1
W = 0.92852, p-value = 0.4335
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
var.test(escala2$Unaided, escala2$Aided1)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```

	F test to compare two variances

data:  escala2$Unaided and escala2$Aided1
F = 20.978, num df = 9, denom df = 9, p-value = 0.000106
alternative hypothesis: true ratio of variances is not equal to 1
95 percent confidence interval:
  5.210754 84.459185
sample estimates:
ratio of variances 
          20.97847 
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
t.test(escala2$Aided1, escala2$Unaided,
       paired = TRUE,
       var.equal = FALSE)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```

	Paired t-test

data:  escala2$Aided1 and escala2$Unaided
t = 4.4214, df = 9, p-value = 0.001668
alternative hypothesis: true mean difference is not equal to 0
95 percent confidence interval:
 0.1147647 0.3552353
sample estimates:
mean difference 
          0.235 
```
:::
:::


## Teste Não Paramétrico

Os testes não paramétricos, também conhecidos como testes livres de distribuição, são métodos estatísticos utilizados para comparar duas ou mais amostras de dados sem a necessidade de supor que os dados sigam uma distribuição normal. Isso os torna úteis em diversas situações, como quando os dados são categóricos ordinais, possuem outliers ou apresentam distribuições não simétricas.


::: {.cell hash='aula6_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-5_da7cc499101de07f27acead43ab646f9'}

```{.r .cell-code}
wilcox.test(escala2$Aided1,
            escala2$Unaided,
            paired = TRUE)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```

	Wilcoxon signed rank test with continuity correction

data:  escala2$Aided1 and escala2$Unaided
V = 55, p-value = 0.005889
alternative hypothesis: true location shift is not equal to 0
```
:::
:::


## Três ou Mais Grupos


::: {.cell hash='aula6_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-6_5fbaccd285ac75ed7751c76360f0dc1f'}

```{.r .cell-code}
micelial <- gsheet2tbl("https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1bq2N19DcZdtax2fQW9OHSGMR0X2__Z9T/edit#gid=959387827")

micelial |>
  ggplot(aes(especie, tcm))+
  geom_jitter(width = 0.05 )
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](aula6_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-6-1.png){width=672}
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
m1 <- lm(tcm ~ especie, data = micelial)
anova(m1)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
Analysis of Variance Table

Response: tcm
          Df  Sum Sq Mean Sq F value    Pr(>F)    
especie    4 1.46958 0.36739  19.629 2.028e-07 ***
Residuals 25 0.46792 0.01872                      
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
summary(m1)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```

Call:
lm(formula = tcm ~ especie, data = micelial)

Residuals:
     Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max 
-0.23667 -0.09667  0.01583  0.08833  0.28333 

Coefficients:
            Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
(Intercept)  1.57167    0.05585  28.140  < 2e-16 ***
especieFaus -0.33500    0.07899  -4.241 0.000266 ***
especieFcor -0.25000    0.07899  -3.165 0.004047 ** 
especieFgra -0.66000    0.07899  -8.356 1.05e-08 ***
especieFmer -0.14500    0.07899  -1.836 0.078317 .  
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

Residual standard error: 0.1368 on 25 degrees of freedom
Multiple R-squared:  0.7585,	Adjusted R-squared:  0.7199 
F-statistic: 19.63 on 4 and 25 DF,  p-value: 2.028e-07
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
medias1 <- emmeans(m1, ~ especie)
cld(medias1)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
 especie emmean     SE df lower.CL upper.CL .group
 Fgra     0.912 0.0559 25    0.797     1.03  1    
 Faus     1.237 0.0559 25    1.122     1.35   2   
 Fcor     1.322 0.0559 25    1.207     1.44   2   
 Fmer     1.427 0.0559 25    1.312     1.54   23  
 Fasi     1.572 0.0559 25    1.457     1.69    3  

Confidence level used: 0.95 
P value adjustment: tukey method for comparing a family of 5 estimates 
significance level used: alpha = 0.05 
NOTE: If two or more means share the same grouping symbol,
      then we cannot show them to be different.
      But we also did not show them to be the same. 
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
hist(m1$residuals)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](aula6_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-6-2.png){width=672}
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
shapiro.test(m1$residuals)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```

	Shapiro-Wilk normality test

data:  m1$residuals
W = 0.9821, p-value = 0.8782
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
bartlett.test(tcm ~ especie, data = micelial)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```

	Bartlett test of homogeneity of variances

data:  tcm by especie
Bartlett's K-squared = 4.4367, df = 4, p-value = 0.3501
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
plot(simulateResiduals(m1))
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](aula6_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-6-3.png){width=672}
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
check_normality(m1)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
OK: residuals appear as normally distributed (p = 0.878).
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
check_heteroscedasticity(m1)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
OK: Error variance appears to be homoscedastic (p = 0.880).
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
check_model(m1)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](aula6_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-6-4.png){width=672}
:::
:::


## InsectSprays

O InsectSprays é um conjunto de dados disponível no R que contém o número de insetos em unidades experimentais agrícolas tratadas com diferentes inseticidas.


::: {.cell hash='aula6_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-7_d9c674892cd5293b283eb96fe80d3cd6'}

```{.r .cell-code}
inseticida <- InsectSprays


inseticida |>
  ggplot(aes(spray, count))+
  geom_boxplot()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](aula6_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-7-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::
